trans-unit.source: Retrieves the permalink structure for categories.
Retrieves the pixel sizes for avatars.
Retrieves the post excerpt.
Retrieves the post pages link navigation for previous and next pages.
Retrieves the post status’ schema, conforming to JSON Schema.
Retrieves the post type of the current post or of a given post.
Retrieves the post type’s schema, conforming to JSON Schema.
Retrieves the post’s schema, conforming to JSON Schema.
Retrieves the previous post link that is adjacent to the current post.
Retrieves the previous post that is adjacent to the current post.
Retrieves the previous posts page link.
Retrieves the publicly-visible data for routes.
Retrieves the query params for collections of attachments.
Retrieves the query params for collections.
Retrieves the query params for the autosaves collection.
Retrieves the query params for the collections.
Retrieves the query params for the posts collection.
Retrieves the query params for the search results collection.
Retrieves the queue for lazy-loading metadata.
Retrieves the raw request entity (body).
Retrieves the registered partials.
Retrieves the request body content.
Retrieves the requested data of the author of the current post.
Retrieves the response data for JSON serialization.
Retrieves the response data.
Retrieves the response object for the request.
Retrieves the revision’s schema, conforming to JSON Schema.
Retrieves the rewrite rules.
Retrieves the route map.
Retrieves the route that matched the request.
Retrieves the route that was used.
Retrieves the screen icon (no longer used in 3.8+).
Retrieves the search params for the themes collection.
Retrieves the search permalink structure.
Retrieves the settings for all instances of the widget class.
Retrieves the settings.
Retrieves the site URL for the current network.
Retrieves the site index.
Retrieves the site setting schema, conforming to JSON Schema.
Retrieves the supported media types.
Retrieves the taxonomy for the current Tag cloud widget instance.
Retrieves the taxonomy object of $taxonomy.
Retrieves the taxonomy relationship to the term object id.
Retrieves the taxonomy’s schema, conforming to JSON Schema.
Retrieves the term’s schema, conforming to JSON Schema.
Retrieves the terms associated with the given object(s), in the supplied taxonomies.
Retrieves the terms for a post.
Retrieves the theme’s schema, conforming to JSON Schema.
Retrieves the type for register_rest_field() in the context of comments.
Retrieves the type for register_rest_field().
Retrieves the user search query results.
Retrieves the user’s schema, conforming to JSON Schema.
Retrieves the userdata and passes it to WP_User::init().
Retrieves the value for an image attachment’s ‘sizes’ attribute.
Retrieves the value for an image attachment’s ‘srcset’ attribute.
Retrieves the widget ID base value.
Retrieves the widget control arguments.
Retrieves the widget control markup parts.
Retrieves the widget control markup.
Retrieves the widget display callback.
Retrieves the widget setting type given a setting ID.
Retrieves the widget update callback.
Retrieves the year permalink structure without month and day.
Retrieves theme installer pages from the WordPress.org Themes API.
Retrieves unvalidated referer from ‘_wp_http_referer’ or HTTP referer.
Retrieves uploads directory information.
Return
Return ALL posts within the category, but don’t show sticky posts at the top. The ‘sticky posts’ will still show in their natural position (e.g. by date):
Return Fields Parameter
Return RegEx body to liberally match an opening HTML tag.
Return Values
Return a data-customize-setting-key-link attribute if a setting is not registered for the supplied setting key.
Return a comma-separated string of functions that have been called to get to the current point in code.
Return a list of slugs of installed plugins, if known.
Return a non-null value to bypass WordPress’s default post queries.
Return a non-null value to bypass WordPress’s default site queries.

Return a non-null value to bypass WordPress’s default user queries. Filtering functions that require pagination information are encouraged to set the total_users property of the WP_User_Query object, passed to the filter by reference. If WP_User_Query does not perform a database query, it will not have enough information to generate these values itself.
Return a set of tests that belong to the site status page.
Return added WP_Customize_Control instance.
Return added WP_Customize_Panel instance.
Return added WP_Customize_Section instance.
Return added WP_Customize_Setting instance.
Return an anonymized IPv4 or IPv6 address.
Return an array of all the available item types.
Return an array of sites for a network or networks.
Return an array representation.
Return an array with IDs of posts maked as sticky.
Return an associative array listing all the views that can be used with this table.
Return an empty value from this filter to allow what WP considers a duplicate comment.
Return count of imported permalinks from WordPress database
Return data about a user request.
Return false if the event does not exist, otherwise an event object should be returned.
Return false to disable trash support for the post.
Return files in the theme’s directory.
Return link to the post RSS feed.
Return null to avoid the short-circuit. Return false if no network can be found at the requested domain and path. Otherwise, return an object from wp_get_network().
Return null to avoid the short-circuit. Return false if no site can be found at the requested domain and path. Otherwise, return a site object.
Return number of visible columns
Return only the main user fields
Return parameters for this control.
Return posts within the category, but exclude sticky posts completely, and adhere to paging rules:
Return relative path to an uploaded file.
Return request confirmation message HTML.
Return statuses for privacy requests.
Return the Ajax wp_die() handler if it’s a customized request.
Return the Ajax wp_die() handler if it’s a customized request.
Return the HTTP protocol sent by the server.
Return the Translations instance for a text domain.
Return the URL of the site
Return the appropriate alias for the given meta type if applicable.
Return the cache key for wp_count_posts() based on the passed arguments.
Return the content type for specified feed type.
Return the current priority level of the currently running iteration of the hook.
Return the default suggested privacy policy content.
Return the entire IRI when you try and read the object as a string
Return the html email link to the author of the current comment.
Return the list of known plugins.
Return the list of users.
Return the names or objects of the taxonomies which are registered for the requested object or object type, such as a post object or post type name.
Return the post thumbnail URL.
Return the total number of users for the current query.
Return true if it’s an Ajax request.
Return true if the current site is not the same as the previewed site.
Return true if the event was scheduled, false if not.
Return true to have the mapped meta caps from edit_{$object_type} apply.
Return uniform “anonymous” data by type.
Return value added to indicate success or failure.
Return value changed from an array to an Requests_Utility_CaseInsensitiveDictionary instance.
Return value format. 'tree' for a hierarchical tree, 'flat' for a flattened array. Default 'tree'.
Return value is sanitize_term() and usage is for sanitizing the term for editing. Function is for contextual and simplicity.
Return value modified to boolean indicating success or failure, 'pre_reschedule_event' filter added to short-circuit the function.
Return value modified to boolean indicating success or failure, 'pre_schedule_event' filter added to short-circuit the function.
Return value modified to boolean indicating success or failure, 'pre_unschedule_event' filter added to short-circuit the function.
Return value modified to indicate success or failure, 'pre_clear_scheduled_hook' filter added to short-circuit the function.
Return value modified to outcome of update_option().
Return values added.
Return whether a post type is compatible with the block editor.
Return whether the post can be edited in the block editor.
Return whether there are published pages.
Returned cookies are represented using this class, and when cookies are set, if they are not already a WP_Http_Cookie() object, then they are turned into one.
Returned values should begin with an <li> tag.
Returning a WP_Error value from the filter will shortcircuit comment insertion and allow skipping further processing.
Returning a falsey value to the filter will disable the ability to override the post lock.
Returning a falsey value to the filter will short-circuit displaying the dialog.
Returning a falsey value will disable the syntax-highlighting code editor.
Returning a falsey value will prevent loading the default embed handlers.
Returning a non-empty value here will short-circuit display of the in-line comment-reply form in the Comments list table, echoing the returned value instead.
Returning a non-false value from the filter will short-circuit the HTTP request and return early with that value. A filter should return either:
Returning a non-false value from the filter will short-circuit the handling and return early.
Returning a non-null value allows to override the default logic, effectively short-circuiting the function.
Returning a non-null value to the filter will short-circuit wp_nav_menu(), echoing that value if $args->echo is true, returning that value otherwise.
Returning a non-null value will effectively short-circuit and avoid a potentially expensive query against postmeta.
Returning a non-null value will effectively short-circuit the function, returning that value instead.
Returning a non-null value will short-circuit adding the event to the cron array, causing the function to return the filtered value instead.
Returning a non-null value will short-circuit the normal process, returning the filtered value instead.
Returning a non-null value will short-circuit the normal rescheduling process, causing the function to return the filtered value instead.
Returning a non-null value will short-circuit the normal unscheduling process, causing the function to return the filtered value instead.
Returning a non-null value will short-circuit the save method, returning that value instead.
Returning a non-null value will short-circuit the unique slug generation, returning the passed value instead.
Returning a positive integer will effectively short-circuit the function.
Returning a truthy value to the filter will effectively short-circuit the new post being inserted, returning 0. If $wp_error is true, a WP_Error will be returned instead.
Returning a truthy value to the filter will skip the current meta object from being exported.
Returning a truthy value, or one that could be evaluated as a WP_Error will effectively short-circuit the installation, returning that value instead.
Returning a value of false will effectively short-circuit setting the current user.
Returning an array will short-circuit the normal retrieval of ready cron jobs, causing the function to return the filtered value instead.
Returning any other value may result in unexpected behaviour.
Returning anything other than an empty string will effectively short-circuit output of the filesystem credentials form, returning that value instead.
Returning false disables the welcome email.
Returning false effectively short-circuits display of the control form.
Returning false to the filter will skip saving the current option.
Returning false to this filter will cancel the redirect.
Returning false to this hook is the recommended way to hide the admin bar. The user’s display preference is used for logged in users.
Returning false will bypass the proxy; returning true will send the request through the proxy. Returning null bypasses the filter.
Returning false will effectively short-circuit display of the widget.
Returning false will effectively short-circuit the widget’s ability to update settings.
Returning false will trigger a PHP version warning to show up in the admin dashboard to administrators.
Returns a WP_Comment object based on comment ID.
Returns a WP_Image_Editor instance and loads file into it.
Returns a WP_Image_Editor instance and loads file into it.
Returns a WP_Error object if get_term() returns an error for any of the matched terms.
Returns a URL to load the Customizer.
Returns a boolean value of true if a scheduled task has been missed and ends processing. If the list of crons is an instance of WP_Error, return the instance instead of a boolean value.
Returns a confirmation key for a user action and stores the hashed version for future comparison.
Returns a contextual HTTP error code for authorization failure.
Returns a custom logo, linked to home.
Returns a date in the GMT equivalent.
Returns a filename of a Temporary unique file.
Returns a filtered list of WP-supported audio formats.
Returns a filtered list of WP-supported video formats.
Returns a link to a post format index.
Returns a link to the feed for all posts by a given author. A specific feed can be requested or left blank to get the default feed.
Returns a link to the feed for all posts in a given category. A specific feed can be requested or left blank to get the default feed.
Returns a link to the feed for all posts in a given term. A specific feed can be requested or left blank to get the default feed.
Returns a list from WordPress.org of popular importer plugins.
Returns a list of devices to allow previewing.
Returns a list of meta keys to be (maybe) populated in wp_update_user().
Returns a listing of all files in the specified folder and all subdirectories up to 100 levels deep.
Returns a navigation menu object.
Returns a post array ready to be inserted into the posts table as a post revision.

Returns a post object containing the information that was autosaved for the specified post. If the optional $user_id is passed, returns the autosave for that user otherwise returns the latest autosave.
Returns a pretty, translated version of a post format slug
Returns a shortlink for a post, page, attachment, or site.
Returns a submit button, with provided text and appropriate class
Returns all navigation menu objects.
Returns all revisions of specified post.
Returns all the block categories that will be shown in the block editor.
Returns an HTML-formatted link using get_author_posts_url().
Returns an absolute server path (eg: /home/user/public_html/wp-content/themes/my_theme), not a URI.
Returns an array of WP_Theme objects based on the arguments.
Returns an array of WP_Theme objects based on the arguments.
Returns an array of WordPress tables.
Returns an array of allowed HTML tags and attributes for a given context.
Returns an array of post format slugs to their translated and pretty display versions
Returns an array of single-use query variable names that can be removed from a URL.
Returns an array of the names of all registered dynamic block types.
Returns an array of user roles for a given user object.
Returns an associative array of registered block data keyed by block name. Data includes properties of a block relevant for client registration.
Returns an object containing the ‘id’, ‘domain’, ‘path’, and ‘site_name’ properties of the network being viewed.
Returns array of network plugin files to be included in global scope.
Returns array of stylesheet names of themes allowed on the network.
Returns array of stylesheet names of themes allowed on the site or network.
Returns array of stylesheet names of themes allowed on the site.
Returns array with imported permalinks from WordPress database
Returns arrays of emoji data.
Returns block output from block’s registered render_callback.

Returns contents of an inline script used in appending polyfill scripts for browsers which fail the provided tests. The provided array is a mapping from a condition to verify feature support to its polyfill script handle.
Returns document title for the current page.
Returns drop-ins that WordPress uses.
Returns either ”, a 3 or 6 digit hex color (with #), or nothing. For sanitizing values without a #, see sanitize_hex_color_no_hash().
Returns either ”, a 3 or 6 digit hex color (without a #), or null.
Returns error instance if value cannot be decoded.
Returns errors property.
Returns false if $base is not absolute, otherwise an IRI.
Returns false if the user cannot manipulate one of the associated settings, or if one of the associated settings does not exist.

Returns false if the user cannot manipulate one of the associated settings, or if one of the associated settings does not exist. Also returns false if the associated section does not exist or if its capability check returns false.
Returns first matched extension from Mime-type, as mapped from wp_get_mime_types()
Returns first matched extension from Mime-type, as mapped from wp_get_mime_types()
Returns first matched mime-type from extension, as mapped from wp_get_mime_types()
Returns first matched mime-type from extension, as mapped from wp_get_mime_types()
Returns if an error occurred during most recent JSON encode/decode.
Returns only allowed post data fields
Returns or Prints link to the author’s posts.
Returns or prints a category ID.
Returns preferred mime-type and extension based on provided file’s extension and mime, or current file’s extension and mime.
Returns reference to the parent theme.
Returns stream of current image.

Returns the ‘home’ option with the appropriate protocol. The protocol will be ‘https’ if is_ssl() evaluates to true; otherwise, it will be the same as the ‘home’ option. If $scheme is ‘http’ or ‘https’, is_ssl() is overridden.
Returns the ‘site_url’ option with the appropriate protocol, ‘https’ if is_ssl() and ‘http’ otherwise. If $scheme is ‘http’ or ‘https’, is_ssl() is overridden.
Returns the ‘site_url’ option with the appropriate protocol, ‘https’ if is_ssl() and ‘http’ otherwise. If $scheme is ‘http’ or ‘https’, is_ssl() is overridden.
Returns the *nix-style file permissions for a file.
Returns the HTML of the sample permalink slug editor.
Returns the ID of the post’s parent.
Returns the JSON object for the post.
Returns the JSON object for the proxied item.
Returns the Site Icon URL.
Returns the URL of the directory used to store personal data export files.
Returns the URL that allows the user to log out of the site.
Returns the URL that allows the user to register on the site.
Returns the URL that allows the user to retrieve the lost password
Returns the URL to the directory of a theme’s “stylesheet” files.
Returns the URL to the directory of a theme’s “template” files.
Returns the URL to the directory of the theme root.
Returns the URLs for CSS files used in an iframe-sandbox’d TinyMCE media view.
Returns the absolute path to the directory of a theme’s “stylesheet” files.
Returns the absolute path to the directory of a theme’s “template” files.
Returns the advanced options for the nav menus page.
Returns the arguments for the help tab on the Edit Site screens.
Returns the canonical URL for a post.
Returns the classes for the comment div as an array.
Returns the columns for the nav menus page.
Returns the content for the help sidebar on the Edit Site screens.
Returns the correct generator type for the requested output format. Allows for a plugin to filter generators on an individual basis using the ‘get_the_generator_$type’ filter.
Returns the correct generator type for the requested output format. Allows for a plugin to filter generators overall the ‘the_generator’ filter.
Returns the current element.
Returns the current version of the block format that the content string is using.
Returns the default TinyMCE settings.
Returns the default annotation for the web hosting altering the “Update PHP” page URL.
Returns the directory used to store personal data export files.
Returns the home URL with the appropriate protocol, ‘https’ is_ssl() and ‘http’ otherwise. If $scheme is ‘http’ or ‘https’, is_ssl() is overridden.
Returns the initialized WP_Http Object
Returns the initialized WP_oEmbed object.
Returns the initialized WP_oEmbed object.
Returns the key of the current element.
Returns the language for a language code.
Returns the list of classes to be used by a meta box.
Returns the loaded MO file.
Returns the main screenshot file for the theme.
Returns the main site ID for the network.
Returns the menu formatted to edit.
Returns the name of a navigation menu.
Returns the navigation to next/previous set of posts, when applicable.
Returns the object subtype for a given object ID of a specific type.
Returns the original input array.
Returns the output array.
Returns the path on the remote filesystem of ABSPATH.
Returns the path on the remote filesystem of WP_CONTENT_DIR.
Returns the path on the remote filesystem of WP_LANG_DIR.
Returns the path on the remote filesystem of WP_PLUGIN_DIR.
Returns the path on the remote filesystem of the Themes Directory.
Returns the post thumbnail caption.
Returns the privacy policy link with formatting, when applicable.
Returns the real mime type of an image file.
Returns the regexp for common whitespace characters.
Returns the results of _get_cron_array() limited to events ready to be run, ie, with a timestamp in the past.
Returns the sanitized value for a given setting from the current customized state.
Returns the screen layout options.
Returns the screen’s per-page options.
Returns the site URL with the appropriate protocol, ‘https’ if is_ssl() and ‘http’ otherwise. If $scheme is ‘http’ or ‘https’, is_ssl() is overridden.
Returns the space used by the current blog.
Returns the suffix that can be used for the scripts.
Returns the term’s parent’s term_ID.
Returns the theme’s post templates for a given post type.
Returns the theme’s post templates.
Returns the upload quota for the current blog.

Returns the user’s primary blog, if they have one and it is active. If it’s inactive, function returns another active blog of the user. If none are found, the user is added as a Subscriber to the Dashboard Blog and that blog is returned.
Returns true if $thing is an object of the WP_Error class.
Returns true if it is; false otherwise.
Returns true if the block type is dynamic, or false otherwise. A dynamic block is one which defers its rendering to occur on-demand at runtime.
Returns useful keys to use to lookup data from an attachment’s stored metadata.
Returns whether the server is running Apache with the mod_rewrite module loaded.
Returns whether the server supports URL rewriting.
ReverbNation
Reverse of is_plugin_active(). Used as a callback.
Revision ID.
Revision post author ID.
Revision3
Revokes Super Admin privileges.
Rewind the comments, resets the comment index and comment to first.
Rewind the loop posts.
Rewind the posts and reset post index.
Rewinds the Iterator to the first element.
Rotates current image counter-clockwise by $angle.
Run a loopback test on our site.
Run an upgrade/installation.
Run scheduled callbacks or spawn cron for all scheduled events.
Run tests to determine if auto-updates can run.
Run the SQL version checks.
Run the wp query to fetch the posts for listing on the edit posts page
Runs WordPress Upgrade functions.
Runs a validation check and sanitizes the value, primarily to be used via the sanitize_callback arguments in the endpoint args registration.
Runs an insert or replace query based on $type argument.
Runs before the schema is upgraded.
Runs just before PHP shuts down execution.
Runs on the ‘activity_box_end’ hook in wp_dashboard_right_now().

Runs the action ‘generate_rewrite_rules’ with the parameter that is an reference to the current WP_Rewrite instance to further manipulate the permalink structures and rewrite rules. Runs the ‘rewrite_rules_array’ filter on the full rewrite rule array.
Runs the initialization routine for a given site.
Runs the required functions to set up and populate the database, including primary admin user and initial options.
Runs the shutdown handler.
Runs the uninitialization routine for a given site.
Runs when the user is logged in.
Runs when the user is not logged in.
S

SECURITY WARNING: This function is NOT intended to be used in circumstances where the authenticity of the IP address matters. This does NOT guarantee that the returned address is valid or accurate, and it can be easily spoofed.
SITENAME### The name of the network.
SITENAME### The name of the site.
SITEURL### The URL to the network.
SITEURL### The URL to the site.
SQL fragment to append to the main JOIN clause.
SQL fragment to append to the main WHERE clause.
SSL utilities for Requests
SVG icon base color.
SVG icon color of current admin menu link.
SVG icon color on focus.
SWFObject
SWFUpload
SWFUpload Degrade
SWFUpload Handlers
SWFUpload Queue
Safely extracts not more than the first $count characters from html string.
Salting passwords helps against tools which has stored hashed values of common dictionary strings. The added values makes it harder to crack.

Salts are created using secret keys. Secret keys are located in two places: in the database and in the wp-config.php file. The secret key in the database is randomly generated and will be appended to the secret keys in wp-config.php.

Same as wp_upload_dir() but "light weight" as it doesn’t attempt to create the uploads directory. Intended for use in themes, when only ‘basedir’ and ‘baseurl’ are needed, generally in all cases when not uploading files.
Same as {@link export}, but writes the result to a file
Sanitises various option values based on the nature of the option.
Sanitize Term all fields.
Sanitize a ‘relation’ operator.
Sanitize a mime type
Sanitize a request argument based on details registered to the route.
Sanitize a theme header.
Sanitize a token list string, such as used in HTML rel and class attributes.
Sanitize a value based on a schema.
Sanitize an input.
Sanitize and validate data required for a user sign-up.
Sanitize content with allowed HTML KSES rules.
Sanitize every post field.
Sanitize every user field.
Sanitize meta value.
Sanitize post IDs for posts created for nav menu items to be published.
Sanitize post field based on context.
Sanitize space or carriage return separated URLs that are used to send trackbacks.
Sanitize the current title when retrieving or displaying.
Sanitize the setting’s value for use in JavaScript.
Sanitize user field based on context.
Sanitized and unique username.
Sanitizes (where possible) the params on the request.
Sanitizes POST values from an input taxonomy metabox.
Sanitizes Term for editing.
Sanitizes a URL for use in a redirect.
Sanitizes a bookmark field.
Sanitizes a filename, replacing whitespace with dashes.
Sanitizes a hex color without a hash. Use sanitize_hex_color() when possible.
Sanitizes a hex color without a hash. Use sanitize_hex_color() when possible.
Sanitizes a hex color.
Sanitizes a multiline string from user input or from the database.
Sanitizes a string and removed disallowed URL protocols.
Sanitizes a string from user input or from the database.
Sanitizes a string key.
Sanitizes a title with the ‘query’ context.
Sanitizes a title, or returns a fallback title.
Sanitizes a title, replacing whitespace and a few other characters with dashes.
Sanitizes a username, stripping out unsafe characters.
Sanitizes a widget instance.
Sanitizes all bookmark fields
Sanitizes an HTML classname to ensure it only contains valid characters.
Sanitizes and validates the list of post statuses, including whether the user can query private statuses.
Sanitizes and validates the list of theme status.
Sanitizes category data based on context.
Sanitizes content for allowed HTML tags for post content.
Sanitizes content from bad protocols and other characters.
Sanitizes data in single category key field.
Sanitizes plugin data, optionally adds markup, optionally translates.
Sanitizes term fields, according to the filter type provided.

Sanitizes the bookmark fields based on what the field name is. If the field has a strict value set, then it will be tested for that, else a more generic filtering is applied. After the more strict filter is applied, if the $context is ‘raw’ then the value is immediately return.
Sanitizes the cookies sent to the user already.
Sanitizes the incoming data, to ensure that it matches the type of data expected, using KSES.
Sanitizes the list of subtypes, to ensure only subtypes of the passed type are included.
Sanitizes the slug value.
Sanitizes the widget form values as they are saved.
Save a file submitted from a POST request and create an attachment post for it.
Save a post submitted with XHR
Save posted nav menu item data.
Save starter content changeset.
Save the post for the loaded changeset.
Save the properties of a menu item or create a new one.
Save the properties of a menu or create a new menu with those properties.
Save the value of the setting, using the related API.
Saves a draft or manually autosaves for the purpose of showing a post preview.
Saves and restores user interface settings stored in a cookie.
Saves current image to file.
Saves current in-memory image to file.
Saves image to file.
Saves image to post along with enqueued changes in $_REQUEST[‘history’]
Saves nav menu items
Saves option for number of rows when listing posts, pages, comments, etc.
Saves the XML document into a file
Saves the data to the cache.
Saves the object cache before object is completely destroyed.
Saves the settings for all instances of the widget class.
Saves the value of the setting, using the related API.
Saving hex colors without a hash puts the burden of adding the hash on the UI, which makes it difficult to use or upgrade to other color types such as rgba, hsl, rgb, and html color names.
Scale an image to fit a particular size (such as ‘thumb’ or ‘medium’).
Scale down an image to fit a particular size and save a new copy of the image.
Scale down the default size of an image.
Scans a directory for files of a certain extension.
Schedule a WP_Cron job to delete expired export files.
Schedule core, theme, and plugin update checks.
Schedule update of the network-wide counts for the current network.
Schedules a hook which will be triggered by WordPress at the specified interval. The action will trigger when someone visits your WordPress site if the scheduled time has passed.
Schedules a hook which will be triggered by WordPress at the specified time. The action will trigger when someone visits your WordPress site if the scheduled time has passed.
Schedules a recurring event.
Schedules an event to run only once.
Screen reader text for nav element. Default 'Comments navigation'.
Screen reader text for nav element. Default 'Post navigation'.
Screen reader text for nav element. Default 'Posts navigation'.
Screen reader text for navigation element. Default 'Posts navigation'.
Screen reader text for the filter links heading. Default 'Filter items list'.
Screen reader text for the items list heading. Default 'Items list'.
Screen reader text for the pagination heading. Default 'Items list navigation'.
Screencast
Screenshot URL, e.g. <a href="https://wordpress.org/themes/twentynineteen/">https://wordpress.org/themes/twentynineteen/</a>.
Screenshots for a theme must be in the stylesheet directory. (In the case of child themes, parent theme screenshots are not inherited.)
Scribd
Scriptaculous
Scriptaculous Builder
Scriptaculous Controls
Scriptaculous Drag & Drop
Scriptaculous Effects
Scriptaculous Root
Scriptaculous Slider
Scripts that have been pre-registered using
Search Parameters
Search all registered theme directories for complete and valid themes.
Search content for shortcodes and filter shortcodes through their hooks.
Search criteria to match terms. Will be SQL-formatted with wildcards before and after.

Search engines consider www.somedomain.com and somedomain.com to be two different URLs when they both go to the same location. This SEO enhancement prevents penalty for duplicate content by redirecting all incoming links to one or the other.
Search for disabled element tags. Push element to stack on tag open and pop on tag close.

Search keyword(s). Prepending a term with a hyphen will exclude posts matching that term. Eg, 'pillow -sofa' will return posts containing 'pillow' but not 'sofa'. The character used for exclusion can be modified using the the 'wp_query_search_exclusion_prefix' filter.
Search keyword. Searches for possible string matches on columns. When $search_columns is left empty, it tries to determine which column to search in based on search string.
Search only inside HTML elements for shortcodes and process them.
Search term(s) to retrieve matching comments for.

Search term(s) to retrieve matching sites for.
Searches for HTML tags, no matter how malformed.
Searches for all of the links, strips them out of the content, and places them at the bottom of the content with numbers.

Searches for metadata in the first 8kiB of a file, such as a plugin or theme. Each piece of metadata must be on its own line. Fields can not span multiple lines, the value will get cut at the end of the first line.
Searches in the STYLESHEETPATH before TEMPLATEPATH and wp-includes/theme-compat so that themes which inherit from a parent theme can just overload one file.
Searches in the stylesheet directory before the template directory so themes which inherit from a parent theme can just override one file.
Searches the object type content for a given search request.
Searches up the list of functions until it reaches the one that would most logically had called this method.
Second of the minute. Accepts numbers 0-60.

Secondly, across various PHP versions, schemeless URLs starting containing a ":" in the query are being handled inconsistently. This function works around those differences as well.

Signature Verification with SoftFail was added.
Similar to _deprecated_function(), but with different strings. Used to remove PHP4 style constructors.
Similar to the ‘oembed_ttl’ filter, but for the REST API oEmbed proxy endpoint.
Simple AJAX Code-Kit

Simple function whose main purpose is to allow filtering of the list of roles in the $wp_roles object so that plugins can remove inappropriate ones depending on the situation or user making edits. Specifically because without filtering anyone with the edit_users capability can edit others to be administrators, even if they are only editors or authors. This filter allows admins to delegate user management.
SimplePie_Cache
SimplePie_File
SimplePie_Sanitize
Since
Since 4.5.0, taxonomies should be passed via the ‘taxonomy’ argument in the $args array:
Since Version 4.9 Introduced the `$comment_count` parameter. It can be either an Integer or an Array.

Since WordPress 2.1, when the static front page functionality was introduced, the blog posts index and site front page have been treated as two different query contexts, with is_home() applying to the blog posts index, and is_front_page() applying to the site front page.

Since WordPress 4.4, oEmbed discovery is enabled for all users and allows embedding of sanitized iframes. The providers in this list are whitelisted, meaning they are trusted and allowed to embed any content, such as iframes, videos, JavaScript, and arbitrary HTML.

Since linear changesets are deemed to be more suitable for the majority of WordPress users, they are the default. For WordPress sites that have heavy site management in the Customizer by multiple users then branching changesets should be enabled by means of this filter.
Since the page template slug is stored inside the
Since the role names are in the database and not in the source there are dummy gettext calls to get them into the POT file and this function properly translates them back.

Since the shortcode needs to be run earlier than other shortcodes, this function removes all existing shortcodes, registers the shortcode, calls do_shortcode(), and then re-registers the old shortcodes.
Since the term can be an object, integer, or string, make sure that any numbers you pass in are explicitly converted to an integer (example:
Since version 3.4 the TinyMCE body has .rtl CSS class. It is a better option to use that class and add any RTL styles to the main stylesheet.
Singleton that registers and instantiates WP_Widget classes.
Singular form to be localized.
Singular form to be localized. No longer used.
Singular label for an object being listed, e.g. 'post'. Default empty
Site Front Page Menu Items
Site data will be cached and returned after being passed through a filter. If the provided site is empty, the current site global will be used.
Site domain. Default empty string.
Site fields to return. Accepts 'ids' (returns an array of site IDs) or empty (returns an array of complete site objects).
Site is provided as context so that a list of network allowed themes can be filtered further.
Site path. Default '/'.

Site status or array of statuses. Accepts 'id', 'domain', 'path', 'network_id', 'last_updated', 'registered', 'domain_length', 'path_length', 'site__in' and 'network__in'. Also accepts false, an empty array, or 'none' to disable ORDER BY clause. Default 'id'.
Site title. Default is 'Site %d' where %d is the site ID.
Site title. Default is 'Site %d' where %d is the site ID. Passed to the wp_initialize_site hook.
Size in bytes of the enclosure.
Size in bytes to limit the response to. Default null.
Size of file in bytes.
Size of the images to display. Accepts any valid image size, or an array of width and height values in pixels (in that order). Default 'thumbnail'.
Slashes will first be removed if magic_quotes_gpc is set, see https://secure.php.net/magic_quotes for more details.
Slideshare
Slug
Slug of the term to make this term an alias of. Default empty string. Accepts a term slug.
Smallest font size used to display tags. Paired with the value of $unit, to determine CSS text size unit. Default 8 (pt).
SmugMug

So, the main purpose of the register functions is to allow you to simplify your code by removing the need to duplicate code if you enqueue the same script or style in more than one section of code. The benefits of this are many and probably don’t need to be listed here.

So, to expose your new, custom query variable to WP_Query hook into the ‘query_vars‘ filter, add your query variable to the $vars array that is passed by the filter, and remember to return the array as the output of your filter function. See below:
Some $show values are deprecated and will be removed in future versions. These options will trigger the _deprecated_argument() function.
Some WordPress functionality is based on the current user and not based on the signed in user. Therefore, it opens the ability to edit and perform actions on users who aren’t signed in.
Some examples of filter hooks generated here include: ‘edit_attachment_per_page’, ‘edit_post_per_page’, ‘edit_page_per_page’, etc.

Some functionality requires API to exist, so some PHP version may lose out support. This is not the fault of WordPress (where functionality is downgraded, not actual defects), but of your PHP version.
Some queries are made before the plugins have been loaded, and thus cannot be filtered with this method.

Some sites may not have the same requirements, for example the automatic update checks may be handled by a host, and are therefore disabled in core. Or maybe you want to introduce a new test, is caching enabled/disabled/stale for example.

Some users have issues with opening large files and manipulating the contents for want is usually the first 1kiB or 2kiB. This function stops pulling in the plugin contents when it has all of the required plugin data.
Someecards
Sort by strlen, longest string first
Sort categories by ID.
Sort categories by name.
Sort menu items by the desired key.
Sort menu objects by the class-supplied orderby property.

Sort retrieved posts by parameter. One or more options may be passed. To use 'meta_value', or 'meta_value_num', 'meta_key=keyname' must be also be defined. To sort by a specific $meta_query clause, use that clause's array key. Accepts 'none', 'name', 'author', 'date', 'title', 'modified', 'menu_order', 'parent', 'ID', 'rand', 'relevance', 'RAND(x)' (where 'x' is an integer seed value), 'comment_count', 'meta_value', 'meta_value_num', 'post__in', 'post_name__in', 'post_parent__in', and the array keys of $meta_query. Default is 'date', except when a search is being performed, when the default is 'relevance'.
Sort retrieved posts.
Sorting direction for $orderby. Accepts 'ASC', 'DESC'. Default 'ASC'.
Sorts a list of objects, based on one or more orderby arguments.
Sorts the list of Categories by the Category name in ascending order
Sorts the list, based on one or more orderby arguments.
Sorts themes by name.

Splitting the query will cause it to fetch just the IDs of the found posts (and then individually fetch each post by ID), rather than fetching every complete row at once. One massive result vs. many small results.

Styles will only be added if the stylesheet is already in the queue. Accepts a string $data containing the CSS. If two or more CSS code blocks are added to the same stylesheet $handle, they will be printed in the order they were added, i.e. the latter added styles can redeclare the previous.
Stylesheet (child theme) to update. Optional, defaults to current theme/stylesheet.
